messageBody:
On 2/16/07, felix3142 <f.noz@...> wrote:
>
> One question that occured is if it's possible to quantify the amount
> of extra time you need when using unit testing compared to the
> non-testing approach. I solely refer to the writing of unit tests.
> Later saving of time (by better code) shouldn't be considered. So
> what's your experience? Can anybody do a statement about time
> consumption of writing unit tests?


It's easy to quantify: How much time do you want to spend?

I"ve found that it's impossible to write unit tests for everything after the
fact, without changing the existing code to make it testable. Usually there
is a module that is so tangled with dependencies that nothing can be tested
in isolation (or a reasonable facisimile thereof).

When you run into one of these tangles, you're faced with a few choices:

1) Decouple the code to make it testable.
2) Write some kind of integration / acceptance test that verifies the inputs
/ outputs. Abandon the unit tests for the dependencies.
3) Ignore that section of the code entirely (This is too hard, and I have a
deadline to meet!)

Every time I run into this situation, I want to choose #1. If the code I'm
working on doesn't require me to change the internals, I might fall back to
#2 in order to meet my deadline. I used to fall back to #3 all too often.
Today I believe that is unprofessional.

When you're estimating how much time you need to spend retrofitting unit
tests, you have to decide which of those options you're comfortable with.
Run some code metrics to determine how tangled the code base is. Look at
some of the more important classes to determine how easy the code is to
understand. I'd take those three elements, add in a dash of what experience
tells me, and then provide a buffer based on the thoroughness of the final
result.

Cheers!
Carl
